posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked:
Good afternoon CD . Team 9068 is looking into the option of casting our own intake rollers, wheels and stars. We have seen several teams have success with using custom cast silicon parts. What we are looking for is: If your team has tried casting your own, what were your Pros and Cons. What should we expect in the way of cost savings, or not. What tips you might have. Lastly, what products did you use?

Links to guides and videos that helped you would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Has anyone casted swerve wheels with geometry similar to 3d printed wheels?

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
3d printed wheels & treads Technical Discussion

TLDR: not worth it for drive wheels IMO.

You can probably make it work for drive wheels under very specific conditions (or for practice with the technique), but better suited for more game specific mechanisms (as the OP was focused on). The benifit you may get just is so marginal at best vs COTS for drive wheels.

posts.name: Steven
posts.cooked:
I personally don’t, but I know that 3161 Tronic Titans has a mentor that’s been casting wheels for them (I have a couple from a shirt trade).

You can find some info on their Open Alliance Thread 2025 . And maybe more on their 2024 OA thread

I believe they did custom molded swerve tread this year but don’t remember the results. @ctxy256 will have more info and be able to direct to who does their casting in house.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked:
I have no advice to offer on the particulars of casting. However, I do have some general advice on the topic: make sure you think hard about why you are pursuing this and what you hope to gain . If the why is “learning” and the what you hope to gain is “student exposure to a new manufacturing process”, then godspeed and good luck, I wish you all the success in the world.

However, if you are looking for a strategic advantage, or even worse

billbo911:

cost savings

then I implore you to reconsider. There is almost certainly no strategic advantage in terms of time or performance over using COTS wheels/rollers as-is or modified as needed; save your time and effort to optimize elsewhere. In terms of cost, between the vacuum set-up and other start-up infrastructure, as well as the necessary quantity of pre-season test wheels and iterations, there is no way you will save money, at least for several years. And the performance will most likely not live up to commercially available injection-molded options anyways.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: Fair comments! Thanks for your input. Weighing out the pros and cons is EXACTLY why we came here for input.

posts.name: Mike Marandola
posts.cooked:
I led the charge in making some in 2013/2014. It was worth it from a fun pov, but doesn’t make sense from a cost and performance aspect these days. We only made them because we could not use a credit card and we got the Smooth-on materials donated.

posts.name: Martin L. M.
posts.cooked:
We’ve had success with running casted swerve tread on sds billet wheels, which we’ve replaced at each of our events (for the sake of testing them more) with little wear. We’ve also had success with custom casting all of the wheels on our robot this year, which gives us better choices for choosing any diameter, durometer, colours, etc. We’ve also casted star wheels that have been run on 5885’s robot, and petunia rollers that have been run on our 2024 robot and been tested by 9062. All of the wheels are casted in urethane.

image 1920×2560 310 KB image 1920×2560 348 KB

image 1920×2560 310 KB

image 1920×2560 310 KB

image 1920×2560 348 KB

image 1920×2560 348 KB

you can contact our mentor who makes and sells these wheels at Urewheels@gmail.com

Zaque:

In terms of cost, between the vacuum set-up and other start-up infrastructure,

This is not necessary if you aren’t driving an FRC robot with the casted wheels (aka intaking like is suggested in the original post). The combat robotics program at my school casts wheels with nothing more than a 3dp mold and the silicone itself, however, I’m not familiar with any of the specifics. Time is still a large investment, but the money investment is not too bad.

In 2023 and 2024 we created our own wheels!

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
1293 didn’t cast our intake wheels this year, but we did print them out of TPU. (Specifically, Polymaker 95A.)

IMG_1278 1920×1440 381 KB IMG_1098 1920×2560 286 KB

IMG_1278 1920×1440 381 KB

IMG_1278 1920×1440 381 KB

IMG_1098 1920×2560 286 KB

IMG_1098 1920×2560 286 KB

As we got deeper into FSC North Charleston, we ran into some traction problems.  With hindsight, we didn’t attempt to clean off the tread surface so I don’t know if that would’ve bailed us out.  We used self-fusing silicone tape instead, which kept us largely in good shape for the rest of the tournament (which was our last one of the season).  We’re going to experiment with printing some actual tread on the wheels this off-season.

What I do know is that it was promising performance at a fraction of what it would’ve cost us to buy COTS compliant wheels.

posts.name: Bumper Fairy
posts.cooked:
Yes. 2960 uses polyurethanes from Smooth-On for our Swerve tyres and various robot parts. I attached our flyer.

We 3D print our wheel hubs and then cast the tyres out of 60A PU. We get insane traction from the softer rubber on all surfaces. We use 3D printed moulds for the casting - usually a 3-piece mould with the center element being TPU (don’t cheap out on mould release here lol). We get 8 matches out of the tyres, which we consider to be excellent for the traction properties. We vacuum the PU prior to pouring, and then do a second light vac after. Once the initial cure is complete, we heat treat for 4 hours.

We also have a lot of room for tread design, which is a lot of fun to play with. One of the kids’ ideas this year basically ate itself due to too much traction. :proud mentor:

We are a little surprised that durability is such a big topic. Our split hub system makes tyre changes very quick and a breeze and we do not have to fool around with screws in the treads.

We use the same casting method for other robot parts - kids figure out what they want, CAD it up, CAM it, print it, and then do the pours under mentor eyes - a lost cast is a huge mess to clean up. Sky is the limit for design this way. Our cage holder was a tiny part of overmoulded PLA. Major props to the student who figured that out - saved us a huge amount of weight.

To the point about cost - yes. We got 4 sets of swerve tyres out of a 2# Smooth-on kit. That is $2 per tyre for silly levels of performance.

Casting sheet for Pit.pdf (2.9 MB)

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked:
Just to add to this, we did it by cutting out sheets of polycarb and bolting them together to make a large mold for it (easier than a 3d print for that large size). Worked great for the size we needed, and release from the smooth surfaces was super easy. IMG20230114145005 1490×1986 311 KB image 982×832 48 KB We even tried a more solid blue one. IMG20230115143220 1490×1986 241 KB But like I said, they were too thin for how large they were, and not useful for what we were trying to do.

IMG20230114145005 1490×1986 311 KB

IMG20230114145005 1490×1986 311 KB

image 982×832 48 KB

image 982×832 48 KB

IMG20230115143220 1490×1986 241 KB

IMG20230115143220 1490×1986 241 KB

I think the size is mostly what got us. If we’d done this smaller radius and thicker, and embedded a 3d printed hub in the center, this could work great for smaller wheels. But these ones were like, 11 inches or something insane.
